_header: Let no man boast of cunning ne virtue

BodAsh59.First Lines:
LEt noman booste of konnyng ne vertueOf tresore ricchesse or of
                    sapienceOf worldely watte al comþe of IhesuCounseyle of coumfort
                    discrecoun prudence…
BodAsh59.Last Lines:
…Called þe Ryver with þe red stremeTo paradyse
                    wardes vn to Ihesu oure Roos
BodAsh59.Attributed Title:
Here foloweþe a balade made of þe transmutacouns of þis
                    worlde with þe refrayde as a midsomer Roos (f. 31v)

CULHh412.First Lines:
Lat no man bost of cunnyng ne verteuOf tresowr richesse nor of
                    sapience…
CULHh412.Last Lines:
…Toward paradyse callyd the rede stremeOf whos .v. wondes
                    print in ȝowre hert a rose Explicit

CamJes56.First Lines:
[L]At no man bost of konnyng nor vertueOf tresoure Riches nor of
                    Sapience…
CamJes56.Last Lines:
…Toward paradise callid þe reede stremeOf whos v woundes
                    prynte in youre herte A Rose
CamJes56.Editions:
Halliwell-Phillipps,  James Orchard,
                        ed.  
             A Selection from the Minor Poems of Don John Lydgate.
Percy Society
         2. London: T. Richard, 1840: 22-6.

CamTCC601.First Lines:
lat noman bost of Connyng nor VertuOf tresour Rychese ner of
                    sapience…
CamTCC601.Last Lines:
…Toward paradyse callyd the Rede stremeOf whose v woundes
                    prynte in your hert a Rose

BLHar2251.First Lines:
LAte noman boste of konnyng nor vertuOf tresour richesse nor of
                    sapience…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Toward paradise callid the Reede streameOf whos fyve woundis
                    prent in youre hert a Rose

BLHar2255.First Lines:
LAt noman booste of konnyng nor vertuOf tresour richesse nor of
                    Sapience…
BLHar2255.Last Lines:
…Toward paradys callyd the rede stremOff whos five woundys
                    prent in your hert a Roose Explicit
BLHar2255.Editions:
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS

Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 393-6.

BLRoy18Axiii.Transcription:
Let no man booste of cunnyng ne vertueNe of wysdome Riches nor of
                    SapienceNor worldly supporte for all comyth of IesuAs Counsaile
                    Comforte consolacion and prudence

HunHM140.First Lines:
Late no man boste of connyng nor vertueOf tresoure riches nor of
                    sapience…
HunHM140.Last Lines:
…Toward paradice called the red stremeOf whose v woundes prynt
                    in your hert a rose
HunHM140.Editions:
Gray,  Thomas.
